div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, August 12, 1953
div1.opener:
August 12, 1953
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Avenue
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I have been working desperately to finish some work before going to Europe. I have
actually worked long hours every night for the last month, honor my delay in writing
to thank you most sincerely for the most interesting survey which you made. You
did a grand job with the problem. I leave today with Mary for a quick trip to Europe,
speaking in Geneva on the 25th of August at the International Congress on Rheumatic
Diseases and will be back, after a short vacation at Lake Como, the week of Septem-
ber 27.

If you are in the mood to do so, I have another problem for you but this is not nearly
so hard as the other one. I have been struck by the fact that I, an outsider, have
been unable to get a complete picture of the personalities of the four members
of the Yellow Fever Board. We know what they did; we know, up to a point, what
they said, but what were they like? We have a picture of Reed as being a stern,
disciplined, dignified character who could unbend on occasion and was quite
friendly to his very close friends and even overly sentimental with his family,
but there you have it in one sentence. We know that Carroll had apparently an
inferiority complex, was shy, stubborn about his work, faithful to Reed, while he
was working with him at least, and so on. I could continue but I think that between
what you know about these men and what you put in your book there has been much lost.
I am not even sure how tall Reed was or how much he weighed and the same goes for
the others. Of course General Kean and others gave me a rather unfavorable opinion
of Carroll in his later years but he must have been a useful individual in his own
way in Cuba. I do not know how much of personality and physical appraisal should
go into my book but it distresses me that I feel that my knowledge of them is in-
complete.

Now my problem is this. Supposing I were the Surgeon General or the President
(Heaven forbid!) and you were my trusted colleague and I wrote and asked you for a
four-page memorandum on each man. What would you write me? Does this appeal to
you? I hope it does. Don't worry about it. Don't start on it until you have thought
it over and if it starts bubbling up in your mind and heart, then it will come out.
I would certainly love to have your appraisal, not in an extensive, but in a con-
fidential way, more than you or anyone else have given it.
div1.closer: Always yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
